hand.section:
The copie of a former letter written to yo
r
L. this 22 of June 1591.

page.lettertext:
fol.156r
May it please your good L. The 13
th
of this moneth
I advertised your L of my being at
Dorkum
w
th
the
Councel of State
, from whence wee tooke o
r
Journey
toward
the armie. But before wee came thether, wee
had worde from
e Count, that the Enemy at
Groninghen
had opened certaine sluces, wherby of six part
about
the towne, there were five overflowen, and
e armie
on
e suddaine forced to dislodge. The possibilitie to
let in the water was neither knowen to
Count William
nor to
e Deputies of
Friesland,
on whome the armie
depended for good direction in
e siege. For they were
all perswaded, that
e mater of those sluces could not
hinder o
r
approaches, nor
e planting of the Artillerie.
But since it fell out otherwise, it was thought convenient
that our forces should p
nt
ly marche toward
Delfzile
w
ch
is a strong fort upon the Ems distant from
Groeninghen northeast, three long dutch miles. The
taking of this fort, because it serveth as a haven to
Groeninghen, was generallie thought of singular importance.
There was order also taken, that
e artillerie, w
ch
was not yet disbarked, but onely kept in a redines in the
ships before Groeninghen, should bee brought to Delfzile
by water. Upon this resolution the Councel of state
finding no securitie for them selves to goe to Delfzile
by land, when
e troupes were departed, went thether
by shippe. Presentlie upon o
r
coming the approaches
were made & as yesternight the Artillerie made ready
to bee planted, wheruppon the Ennemy w
th
in albeit for
the space of three daies hee had shott uppon us very hotly
upon the first summoning condescended to a parle, and
fol.156v
surrendred presently upon like composition, as those of
Deventer
and
Zutphen.
Their want w
th
in was both
of men and powder, and no kinde of hope to be
relieved by
e Spaniard. Gorningen excepted, there
are onely now remaining in
e territory of Groeningen the
forte of
Opslacht
and
Emmentile,
w
ch
are fort
of some
strength, lieng southwest from Groningen w
th
in 2 or 3
leagues, but unable to w
th
stand any forceable batterie.
For w
ch
it is resolved, that they shalbee summoned out of
hand. And as for those of Groningen it is first
intended, for that now it is thought they will hearken to
reason, that they shalbee moved by faire offers, to unite
them selves to the other Provinces. W
ch
if they chance to
reject, as moste men think they will, reposing no confidence
in any promise of the
States,
then they do determine, as
I am told underhand (for as yet of them selves they doe
not signifie so much unto mee) to use her
Ma
ts
countenance by my meanes, to the effect of that
commission w
ch
was graunted unto mee about 12 moneth
agoe. For mine owne part, because it is a
matter that doth touche them s elves, and because I
knowe it is their humor not to use her Ma
tie
, but as
a refuge in extremitie, I do not deale by
swasion
either on waie or other. For if they cannot speed
of themselves, they will come verie willinglie to crave
her Ma
ts
assistance, and otherwise for mee to move
them therunto, considering how sleightlie they regarded it
before, I knowe not how it would stand w
th
her
Ma
ts
hono
r
. Howbeit I do see aswell by this, as by
many other their proceeding
, that whoseover will not
fol.157r
beare w
th
their diffidence, and jalousie, and other
natural imperfections, but exact more precisely an
honorable cariage in their dealing, then the advauncement
of an action, shall but hinder that in the end, w
ch
mighte bee otherwise effected, and do her Ma
tie
in this
countrey verie litell good service. Wee have certain
information both by l
res
intercepted, and other
verie good intelligence that
e
Duke of
Parma
is
lodged in a cloister called
Marienboome
adjoyning to
e
fort of
Rees,
verie much distressed for lack of vittailes
and carriage, so as now wee are
swaded, that his
journey is wholie staid, for troubling thes quarters.
Besides, his nombers to
e uttermoste are not thought
to exceed 6000 foote and 150 horse, w
ch
are also in
dissention, and in very great miserie, for verie many
great want
. In effect, for my self I did never
yet
ceave, that either the ennemy in these countreys
was ever so perlexed, or so likelie in all places to bee
dishonored in his actions, as hee is at this p
nt
,
and thus I take my humble leave. At
e campe
before Delfzile, where wee make our entry this morning
June the 22 1591.
